messageBody:
Well it sounds like you are most definitely doing some sort of functional testing, so I'll base my comments on that. If your issue is simply that you want to guarantee the ordering of your test cases, you can cheat by having white box knowledge of the implementation of junit. If you don't use the reflection method of adding tests (i.e. - explicitly adding the test) you know that the tests will execute in the same order in which they were added. Note that JUnit does not advertise any contract in this area and the underlying implementation of test case execution could change at any release.

If your issue is that you want to have multiple failures in a given test case before failing the test case, there are some alternatives out there. Search the forum for multiple failures. To answer your question on doing a one time setup for all of your tests - check the FAQ.

Functional testing of API's have many of the same design and usage patterns of any functional test tool out on the market. Keep in mind that if tests have dependencies - you will effectively be blocked from executing dependent tests when you encounter a failure. This has a bad smell, weather you are doing functional, unit - or using a commercial tool like Silk or LoadRunner. That being said, sometimes it does make sense to couple test cases, or a series of test cases - but you need to understand the tradeoffs before doing this.



Cheers,
Bill

something in the database and test x uses the same data to verify
some additional testcases.
We started to examine jxunit, unfortunately it is not that well
documented..

cheers
